properties.title: Beautiful Julia
properties.description: PeteTsai posted a photo: I asked my fire spinning friend Julia if she would model for me for my Beautiful Motion Series. She agreed and I couldn't be happier, she's so pretty and I wanted to capture that in an image. So before we started the dancing we shot some beauty shots. I wanted to get her fire hot red hair moving so I had my friend Bea hold a fan below her and blow both sides of her face. I shot this with a longer lens, a 70-200mm at 1/20th of a second to get enough ambient to blur in the hair movement. McNally shows the technique off quite a bit and I can see why now. I really like the 3D feel the background blur creates of her hair in motion. Strobist info: One light for this one, a Ranger Quadra with Deep Octa at camera right. Studio overhead lights were on creating some ambient. Model: Julia H. Photographer: Pete Tsai MUA: Cait O. Hair: Lizzi H. Assistants: Critter, Bea, and Piotr

properties.title: Misery Loves Company
properties.description: benchorizo posted a photo: This was taken Uptown by Foster Avenue Beach. Just bad weather yesterday. Not too cold but with a steady drizzle that seemed to last all day. Planned to do some skyline shots but ended up with this. I loved how the lighthouse and the tree seemed to look like they're keeping each other company during the cold winter months. Also, I contemplated converting this to B&W but it really didn't make that much difference since everything looked gray anyway. So, here it is in all it's vivid glory. :) Please View On Black .

properties.title: Two luminous pink orbs
properties.description: alienparrot posted a photo: Sometimes there will even be more than one pink ball. At night, they light up the dead streets of The Loop, guiding people back to their respective subway entrances. When all is dark and silent, the luminous pink orbs can freely cavort the city and roll around picking up trash and sanitizing everything. I have not actually seen this for myself, but it is my most probable theory.

properties.title: Two for One
properties.description: benchorizo posted a photo: This is another one of my fireworks shots during the 4th of July celebrations in Chicago. We staked out our spot on the edge of Belmont Harbor hoping to catch the Navy Pier fireworks (on right) but ended up with a bonus. It so happened that there was another fireworks display coming from nearby (maybe the Lincoln Park Zoo or Diversey Harbor) and we were treated to two shows at the same time. And the best part, it was not crowded at all. Had to crop out some heads at the bottom of the frame.View Large

properties.title: Exteriors - Evening
properties.description: bossbob50 posted a photo: It gets complicated. www.youtube.com/watch?v=3GqqRrn-Z9U - Land of One Thousand Trances 1. Sometimes it is the people on the street that catch my eye and I try to catch them in my viewfinder.. 2. Other times it is the geometry of the scene - the buildings, streets, angles, lines and the one-thousand-and-one tiny details that form a cohesive, yet fluid and ever-changing whole. 3. Then at others it has something to do with the quality and color of the light: its harshness, its softness, the way it envelopes the scene, bringing forth certain details, muting others. Often, it is a combination of things - all of which I either don't know or of which I am unaware. I am looking in the viewfinder and it is all a mix of shape, color, form and movement. Apparently, after all of these decades shooting, my brain is able to sort things out - even if my eyes cannot quite, as I often get results I find interesting as starting points. A final, important-to-critical aspect of an image like this - at the time it is taken - is sound. It is a mix of human, city and natural sounds that intermix so uniquely, deeply, yet subtly that over time for us city people, the sounds of real nature and solitude come across as too quiet, odd, jarring or disorienting. I use music to convey what I hear when I'm taking shots such as this: the drone of traffic and machine, the hum of conversation and shuffling feet, the whoosh of wind, the ebb and flow of movement, the rhythmic sounds of urban construction and renovation projects conducted in the distance. Such as the music attached. This is right across the street from my office. Its shapes, action, colors and light catch me often as I leave work, and I have to stop, dig out the camera and catch a few shots. As they were not planned, or consciously considered moments, I usually forget them, and into the folder "to be worked on" they go. There is one final thing influencing my taking of such shots, the work of an extraordinary street-photographer named Joewig: www.flickr.com/photos/joewig/5217401105/in/photostream (Joseph Wigfall). He works people, almost exclusively, while, in general I tend to combine people and their environment with aspects of structure holding my of the comp than the humans. But, what Joewig does is in my heart and I'm trying to do more of it. Textures by: Flypaper ~ www.flickr.com/groups/flypapertextures/ Skeltalmess ~ www.flickr.com/photos/skeletalmess/sets/72157624093222741/ Distressed Jewell ~ www.flickr.com/photos/jewellofdistressed/

properties.title: Summertime Street Life
properties.description: Viewminder posted a photo: It's been the most awesome summer so far... Man... I haven't had this much fun in gahd knows how long. I'm feeling free again. I'm feeling like myself again. It feels really good to be on the right path. The girls'll be on a plane to Portland and I've got the better part of a month to myself! I gotta get a backpacking trip in and I'll be doing a lot of street shooting too. The sunshine's been great for shooting the faces I see on the street... But the sunglasses... they've been a problem... it seems like everyone's wearing them. I hope you're enjoying your summer too... exploring... diggin' a little 'summer love' and feelin' like everything's alright. Faces on the street Chicago 6.26.11 35mm 1.8 contrast intensified

properties.title: Fern Room Overview
properties.description: Andy Marfia posted a photo: The Fern Room at the Garfield Park Conservatory. The Conservatory was hit last week by golf ball sized hail, which left this room, as well as several others, severely damaged. © Andy Marfia 2011

properties.title: Fern Room Ceiling
properties.description: Andy Marfia posted a photo: The Fern Room at the Garfield Park Conservatory. The Conservatory was hit last week by golf ball sized hail, which left this room, as well as several others, severely damaged. I stopped by yesterday to take these photos. The Conservatory is open to the public, but currently only 3 of the 8 display houses are accessible. The 103 year old building is truley one of the unsung gems of Chicago, and it's heartbreaking to see it in such condition. I took this and the next two photos from the adjacent Palm House. City workers were actively working to put up barriers to seal off the fern room, but they allowed me to peer inside to take these photos. © Andy Marfia 2011

properties.title: Creating a tabletop sunset
properties.description: Rigib posted a photo: This was a challenge indeed ... creating a "golden hour" setting. I wanted long shadows, a fuzzy horizon, a sun, orange sky. I knew the light had to be from the back from a previous challenge on backlighting so there are three lamps all pointing toward the orange paper away from Farmer Smurf. I tried using a bit of yellow paper, but it didn't work out so I ended up with just two sheets of orange, which are more orangey than this photo shows, at a right angle to each other. Green paper in the foreground. The sun was created with a small flashlight. handheld just above Farmer Smurf's head but pointing at the same spot you see here. I used the Canon 60mm close-up lens (my favorite of all lens) set on f/2.8. White balance was set to "cloudy" which gave it more orangeyness. I manually focused on Farmer Smurf's tail. Voila!

properties.title: On the Turning Away
properties.description: Viewminder posted a photo: On the turning away From the pale and downtrodden And the words they say Which we won't understand "Don't accept that what's happening Is just a case of others' suffering Or you'll find that you're joining in The turning away" It's a sin that somehow Light is changing to shadow And casting it's shroud Over all we have known Unaware how the ranks have grown Driven on by a heart of stone We could find that we're all alone In the dream of the proud On the wings of the night As the daytime is stirring Where the speechless unite In a silent accord Using words you will find are strange And mesmerised as they light the flame Feel the new wind of change On the wings of the night No more turning away From the weak and the weary No more turning away From the coldness inside Just a world that we all must share It's not enough just to stand and stare Is it only a dream that there'll be No more turning away?No More Turning Away Faces on the street Chicago 6.26.11 35mm 1.8 who knows what I did to this one

properties.title: Psychic mind powers able to push elevator buttons
properties.description: spudart posted a photo: I walk from the Tribune Tower lobby to the elevators and a guy walks out, so I grab the door and hop in. Nobody else is in the elevator, but MY very floor button is already pushed! Floor 14. I exclaimed, "Sweet! Wow!" I MUST have used psychic mind powers to push that button, and I didn't even realize it. Is that dangerous to have this mind ability and not even realize it with your own mind? Four more crazy things happened on my commute one morning. What else happened? Find out at www.spudart.org/blogs/randomthoughts_comments/5427_0_3_0_C/

properties.title: Cherry Avenue Bridge
properties.description: the_mel posted a photo: A view of the Cherry Avenue Bridge looking north on Goose Island.

properties.title: Superhuman mind powers of duplication
properties.description: spudart posted a photo: All this time during my commute I was carrying a tripod with me. I get to work, and there's a tripod on the ground already. What! How did another tripod get there? Then I realized my dad loaned me two tripods, but for a couple seconds I thought my mind created a duplicate tripod on the ground. Answer? Superhuman mind powers of duplication. Four more crazy things happened on my commute one morning. What else happened? Find out at www.spudart.org/blogs/randomthoughts_comments/5427_0_3_0_C/

properties.title: Circui
properties.description: the_mel posted a photo: The Cherry Avenue Bridge with a chimney formerly adorned with the now defunct Circuit City. Why they didn't paint over the entire thing, I know not.

properties.title: Jedi mind powers makes garbage truck stalk me
properties.description: spudart posted a photo: A stinky garbage truck passed me in the alley. It was a big stinkeroo. I stood in Giddings Plaza to take a photo of the word "CHICAGO" written in chalk on the brick pavers. But I almost didn't take the photo, because I was thinking, "Gee, this stink is SO BAD." I continue my normal walk to the train station, and the very same garbage truck passes me by on another street! Stalker garbage truck! The truck read my mind and crossed my path again! Jedi mind powers! Four more crazy things happened on my commute one morning. What else happened? Find out at www.spudart.org/blogs/randomthoughts_comments/5427_0_3_0_C/

properties.title: Chicago -- Traffic Jam? -- A Boater's Perspective -- A Biker's Perspective -- Lake Michigan
properties.description: ellenbusse posted a photo: After my heart surgery, I used to ride the bike path along Lake MI several days a week. My doctor wanted me to go to rehab -- but this was my idea of rehab!!! A little off the bike path at one of the harbors. I used to know which one. I used to park at Montrose Harbor (used to be free parking) and ride from harbor to harbor. Got to know many of the boaters and would often have lunch with a few of them. I rode from Montrose to south of McCormick Place. Such beauty!!! Does wonders for the heart! Not sure about detailed map location. This is a scan from an old 35mm photo. 023_20

properties.title: Sanctuary. A scene from Transformers 3 was filmed right here in this room. Abandoned City Methodist Church in Gary, Indiana. HDR
properties.description: slworking2 posted a photo: The city of Gary, Indiana was founded as a booming steel city as the twentieth century passed, and areas downtown saw the construction of several impressive buildings during these prosperous early years. In 1925, a cornerstone ceremony took place at 577 Washington St. to commemorate the construction of a Gothic Revival church called City Methodist. It was completed 21 months later, at the cost of one million dollars - $385,000 of which was contributed by the United States Steel Corp. (which also founded the city). Elbert Gary, the chairman of U.S. Steel and origin of the city's name, donated a Skinner organ as well. The Bedford limestone structure consisted of a 50-foot tall sanctuary nave and elaborate stonework, and was able to seat 950 worshipers; City Methodist had a congregation of nearly 3,000 members in its heyday. The building was also home to Seaman Hall - a 1,000 seat auditorium, and a gymnasium with a full size basketball court. Storefronts were built into the building, with hopes that the income would offset the enormous maintenance costs. During the 1920s, Pastor William Seaman rallied against the power of the Ku Klux Klan in Indiana, and welcomed black worshipers into City Methodist during a time when African Americans were not permitted in "white churches." Gary entered a downward spiral during the 1960s, like many other industrial cities during the period. As U.S. Steel employment dwindled, the residents of Gary moved to nearby suburbs; then as jobs left downtown, city many residents moved out altogether while crime and poverty rose. By 1973 the church's congregation had only 300 members and by 1975 the Methodists moved out of the structure. A second congregation occupied the building until they left in the early 1980s; some storefronts and office space was utilized for a while but soon the entire campus was completely abandoned. City Methodist was burned in the Great Gary Arson of 1997, resulting in a large portion of the roof collapsed or missing. It is now owned by the city of Gary, and its future remains unclear.

On the plus side, McDonalds was only two blocks down the road.

properties.title: JoJo
properties.description: Rigib posted a photo: Fancy Nancy is a popular storybook character, created by Jane O'Connor. She likes everything fancy so fills her life with frills and lace and glamour. JoJo is Fancy Nancy's little sister. For many, many books she wasn't even given a name. I love her bright face and happy smile. She stands next to the kitchen sink by my radio ... the only doll in the kitchen. She sees most of my photo taking, my cooking and dish washing, my eating, my Sudoku puzzling, my bill paying, my cat feeding, my tax preparing ... a great deal of my life. If I could only keep one doll, it would be JoJo.Portrait - Our Daily Challenge 98# of 365

properties.title: A secret elevator that goes only to the underground!
properties.description: spudart posted a photo: I am so totally geeked that the Chicago Cultural Center has an elevator whose sole purpose is to bring people to the underground of Chicago. I was in Macy's cafeteria and decided to take a different way out. On my way I passed a decent looking sports bar called "insiders" (decent for being in the basement of Macy's). And then the non-descript corridor went by a few weird shops, a Subway sandwich place, and then there was this elevator that said, "Elevator to Chicago Cultural Center." Uh Excuse me? Certainly this sign could not be telling the truth. I love riding different elevators. So I took this one wondering where in the world it would drop me off in the Cultural Center. The elevator slowly rose up, and then paused and nothing. I thought I was stuck. In an unknown elevator. Good thing I have a mozzarella cheese sandwich for sustenance. A few seconds later when I thought I was going to be stranded forever and ever, the elevator continued rising a little bit more. The doors opened up and there was the north lobby of the Cultural Center! Talk about twilight zone experience! Talk about transformers space bridge! There I was. Standing right at the entrance of the Cultural Center. I exclaimed out loud, "WOW! THAT WAS TOTALLY WEIRD!" A couple sitting in the chairs by the elevator looked up from their books and then looked back down. I took a few photos even though those chair people readers were in my way. I didn't care. I wanted a photo of the this space bridge elevator. Then the helper dude at the helper dude desk looked kinda bored, and i looked kinda excited. So I went over to him to exclaim my delight. He became equally delighted and shared with me that there is a Chicago Pedway Tour every Saturday. So going on THAT!

properties.title: Gold Coast Art Fair
properties.description: Flint Foto Factory posted a photo: I had some time to kill before the euchre tournament yesterday. The chain of events went something like this: I went downtown to Blicks Art Supplies after early service to look for a purple mat, but they hadn't opened yet. I spotted some people with yellow t-shirts advertising the Gold Coast Art Fair in Grant Park, and decided to check it out. If it weren't for the euchre tournament (which I co-won - I'm geeking out like Milhouse), I could have spent all afternoon at this art fair. Maybe, one day I'll be a participant.

properties.title: The Belmont, Home of Angelo "Bloody Angelo" Genna
properties.description: Chicago Crime Scenes posted a photo: Angelo Genna, aka "Bloody Angelo," was one of the six famous Genna brothers. Members of the Chicago's Sicilian Mafia, they specialized in bootlegging industrial or corn syrup alcohol. The Gennas' transgressions into the Irish North Side gang's territory led to conflicts with Dean O'Banion, South Side gang leader Johnny Torrio and Unione Siciliane boss Mike Merlo. Angelo is believed to have been murdered by George "Bugs" Moran and Vincent "Scehemer" Drucci after a high-speed car chase on May 27, 1925. Located at 3170 N. Sheridan Road.

properties.title: Jesse Bouley ~ Photographer
properties.description: Viewminder posted a photo: I met Jesse at the Gold Coast Art Fair. I hadda pop him because he's a photographer and that's just like a rule of mine... I love makin' fellow photographers squirm when I pop 'em. Jesse was alright about it though... he's a good guy. He was exhibiting his photographs of 'urban decay' there at the art fair. Jesse 'explores abandoned architecture and documents it as it is reclaimed by the elements.' He's really got some great shots. You can check out Jesse's work here... jessebouley.com/tow_main.html Shoot me a call Jesse or throw me a 'mail buddy... we'd love to go and shoot that theater with you! Faces on the street Chicago 7.9.11 35mm 1.8 SOOC with a tap on the contrast
